docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Ian Wilmut, the scientist who created the cloned sheep Dolly, said today that he intended to try again to clone an adult animal. He said he expected to use cells from a live animal rather than those from the dead ewe that he used to create Dolly. Dr. Wilmut, who works at the Roslin Institute in Edinburgh, stunned the world a year ago when he announced that he had taken an udder cell from an adult sheep that had died three years earlier and used it to create a lamb that was the identical twin of that sheep.

headline.main: Creator of Cloned Sheep Says He Will Try to Repeat Process

docs.abstract: Dr Ian Wilmut says he will try again to clone an adult animal, this time using cells from a live animal rather than those from the dead ewe that he used to create Dolly; Dr Norton D Zinder has charged that using a dead animal's cells foreclosed a direct comparison of Dolly with the donor animal, which would have proved that Dolly was indeed a clone; Wilmut says he believes cloning of humans will be possible one day, but voices misgivings about the unusual family relationships it would create (M)
docs.snippet: Dr. Ian Wilmut, the scientist who created the cloned sheep Dolly, said today that he intended to try again to clone an adult animal. He said he expected to use cells from a live animal rather than those from the dead ewe that he used to create Dolly....

docs.lead_paragraph: After three intense weeks of the most graphic national discussion of sex in the history of the Republic, we have finally arrived at . . . Valentine's Day. How can we reclaim romance from a culture in which lovemaking is now a transaction to be described by Peeping Toms, recorded on tape, collected as DNA evidence and parsed into semantic distinctions that are the legal answer to the Kama Sutra? Forget Sinatra. The old songs have been so burdened by his advance obituaries that they summon up mortality, not romance. Love poetry? Ted Hughes's newly published ''Birthday Letters'' to Sylvia Plath memorialize a marriage that ended in suicide. A play? Off Broadway's ''Shopping and . . .'' cannot even be called by its full title here because it reduces love to an animalistic verb. A movie? Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet are too young for some of us -- young enough to be, well, Monica Lewinsky.
docs.abstract: Frank Rich Op-Ed column says Valentine's Day celebrants should visit exhibit at Museum of American Folk Art in New York City to view perfect esthetic counterweight to bottomless vulgarity of Monica Lewinsky scandal; says art of A G Rizzoli are valentines in form of densely detailed architectural drawings of people he loved; says Rizzoli was probably psychotic, but on this soiled Valentine's Day, his pure-hearted romantic hallucinations loom as soul of mental health; Rich accuses Susan Carpenter-McMillan, pro-life activist, of hypocrisy for fighting against legal abortions, even in cases of rape or incest, while admitting she had abortion and later a therapeutic abortion which she prefers to call miscarriage (M)
docs.snippet: After three intense weeks of the most graphic national discussion of sex in the history of the Republic, we have finally arrived at . . . Valentine's Day. How can we reclaim romance from a culture in which lovemaking is now a transaction to be...

docs.lead_paragraph: Three of the most popular magazines for teen-age girls -- Seventeen, Teen and YM -- have been pulled from the library of a Long Island middle school by the district's Superintendent following complaints by a group of parents and a priest over the sexually oriented material in the magazines. The Superintendent, Dr. Paul A. Lochner, ordered the magazines removed from the Hauppauge Middle School even after an advisory committee of teachers, administrators and a parent voted to keep the publications.

headline.main: Magazines Found Too Adult for School

docs.abstract: Hauppauge, NY, Schools Supt Paul A Lochner orders popular teen-age magazines Seventeen, Teen and YM removed from middle school libraray following complaints by group of parents and Msgr E Raymond Walden over sexually oriented material in magazines; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Three of the most popular magazines for teen-age girls -- Seventeen, Teen and YM -- have been pulled from the library of a Long Island middle school by the district's Superintendent following complaints by a group of parents and a priest over the...

docs.lead_paragraph: How do you reinvent an opera? If the opera is Saint-Saens's biblical chestnut ''Samson et Dalila'' and the director is the veteran stage innovator Elijah Moshinsky, working with Richard Hudson, who designed sets for ''The Lion King,'' the process begins with a vision: a color. The color is orange.
docs.abstract: Metropolitan Opera's new production of Samson et Dalila, directed by Elijah Moshinsky, will feature sets and costumes designed by Richard Hudson that are unusual for bold use of color; both say vibrant color is essential to complement theme of psychosexual obsession; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. David Satcher won Senate confirmation today as Surgeon General, becoming the first person in more than three years to fill a post that has become a lightning rod in the nation's battles over abortion and family values. Dr. Satcher, the 56-year-old director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, a Federal agency whose headquarters are in Atlanta, prevailed on a vote of 63 to 35 after conservatives led by Senator John Ashcroft of Missouri, an aspiring Republican Presidential nominee, fell far short of the 60 votes needed to prevent a vote on President Clinton's nominee.

headline.main: Surgeon General Nominee Is Confirmed, Filling a 3-Year Void

docs.abstract: Senate, 63-35, confirms Dr David Satcher as Surgeon General, first person to fill controversial post in over three years; acts after conservatives, led by Sen John Ashcroft, fall far short of 60 votes needed to bar vote; Pres Clinton hails Satcher; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Dr. David Satcher won Senate confirmation today as Surgeon General, becoming the first person in more than three years to fill a post that has become a lightning rod in the nation's battles over abortion and family values.    Dr. Satcher, the...

docs.lead_paragraph: For 40 days last year, Linda Creager prepared dinner and sat down with her two sons at the table, but ate nothing. For 40 consecutive days she fasted, swallowing nothing but liquids. Ms. Creager says she was not on a diet, but on a religious mission, to find guidance from God. ''After four or five days I didn't even want food,'' said Ms. Creager, a church outreach worker in Birmingham, Ala. ''I could really see how great it's going to be when we don't have to eat anymore, when we get to heaven.''

headline.main: In Hope of Spiritual Revival, a Call to Fast

docs.abstract: Thousands of evangelical Christians, hopeful that nation is on threshold of huge spiritual revival, have quietly taken to preparing by fasting and praying, on their own and in large groups; now prominent evangelicals, led by Bill Bright of Campus Crusade for Christ and Pat Robertson of Christian Broadcasting Network, are calling for two million Christians to join in national 40-day fast beginning on March 1 and ending on April 9, day before Good Friday--roughly coinciding with Lent, period of penance preceding Easter; photos of Bright and of Rev Ronnie W Floyd (L)
docs.snippet: For 40 days last year, Linda Creager prepared dinner and sat down with her two sons at the table, but ate nothing. For 40 consecutive days she fasted, swallowing nothing but liquids. Ms. Creager says she was not on a diet, but on a religious mission,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Kevin Masaquiza was born last Wednesday in a big double bed, in a room with glorious views of the East River. Flower-flecked paper covered the walls, which were decorated with bright framed pictures. In the corner of the room was a glass-enclosed Jacuzzi, where his mother could have relaxed while she was in labor. By the looks of it, Ines Masaquiza could have been delivering her second son in a luxury Manhattan hotel. In fact, Kevin's mother, a sewing-machine operator, was the first woman to give birth in Bellevue Hospital Center's new birthing center, which opens officially tomorrow.

headline.main: At Bellevue, Luring Back New Mothers With Luxury

docs.abstract: Bellevue Hospital Center's luxurious new birthing center opens officially on Feb 9; center is part of multimillion-dollar attempt to reverse trend that is troubling to public hospitals in New York City: defection of low-income, Medicaid-insured pregnant women to private hospitals that once shunned them; photo of Ines Masaquiza, first woman to give birth in new center (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Many medical groups and women's advocates have for years been concerned about what they call a gender gap in health coverage: Although health plans generally cover prescription drugs, most exclude contraceptives, which results in more out-of-pocket expenses for women than for men. But a closely watched effort in California to change coverage plans appears headed for defeat.

headline.main: Effort to Cover Contraception Likely to Fail

docs.abstract: Many medical groups and women's advocates have for years been concerned about what they call gender gap in health coverage: although health plans generally cover prescription drugs, most exclude contraceptives, which results in more out-of-pocket expenses for women than for men; but a closely watched effort in California to change coverage plans appears headed for defeat; Gov Pete Wilson must decide whether to sign legislation requiring health plans that cover prescription drugs to cover many contraceptives as well; Wilson spokesman says that Wilson is leaning strongly toward a veto (M)
docs.snippet: Many medical groups and women's advocates have for years been concerned about what they call a gender gap in health coverage: Although health plans generally cover prescription drugs, most exclude contraceptives, which results in more out-of-pocket...

docs.lead_paragraph: After four miscarriages and eight unsuccessful attempts at artificial insemination, Melody Moreau took in a foster child, a baby boy, from the New York Foundling Hospital in March 1983. In late 1984, she and her husband, John LiGrecci, adopted the boy, whom they named Justin. But from the day he arrived, Justin, now 14, suffered from infections and remained underweight. In 1994, a blood test revealed the cause: H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

headline.main: Lawsuit Against a Hospital Over an Adopted Boy's H.I.V. Is Seen as a First

docs.abstract: Wrongful adoption lawsuit, believed to be the first of its kind, is filed by Melody Moreau against New York Foundling Hospital over child with AIDS virus; suit contends that the hospital failed in 1984 to disclose relevant medical information, such as birth mother's drug addiction, that might have revealed that child was infected; photo of Moreau and 14-year-old Justin (M)
